physical_appearance:A red lacquered box is depicted in the picture. The cover of the box is decorated with two peonies that are golden in colour. In between the two peonies
 there are Chinese characters stating the name of the Cantonese restaurant
 Nantang
 the phone number of the restauranr
 and its address and telephone number. These characters are written in a vertical alignment
 running from the top to bottom. The circular cover has a golden circumference at its edges. The cover of the box looks to have several scratches on it.
subject_terms_1:lacquerware packing material gift giving customs (social) flower (motif) weddings (ceremonies)
subject_terms_2:Motifs Lacquer boxes Gifts Marriage customs and rites
subject_terms_3:Marriage customs
sgcool_label_text:The post-war period saw the establishment of several famous Chinese restaurants in Tua Po (Kreta Ayer area)
 including Nantang Restaurant at 8 Mosque Street and Da Dong Restaurant
 which was just a few doors away on the same street. Judging from the five-digit telephone number on the box
 it is possibly dated to the fifties and sixties. It was imported from Hong Kong
 with the name of the import company or the lacquerware maker inscribed on its base.      \r\nThe box
 made of bamboo and lacquered in an auspicious red
 was traditionally used as a container for wedding pastries. The bride’s family would distribute boxes of these to relatives and friends ahead of the wedding
 often together with the wedding invitation card.

metadata.physical_appearance: A red lacquered box is depicted in the picture. The cover of the box is decorated with two peonies that are golden in colour. In between the two peonies, there are Chinese characters stating the name of the Cantonese restaurant, Nantang, the phone number of the restauranr, and its address and telephone number. These characters are written in a vertical alignment, running from the top to bottom. The circular cover has a golden circumference at its edges. The cover of the box looks to have several scratches on it.
metadata.subject_terms_1: lacquerware packing material gift giving customs (social) flower (motif) weddings (ceremonies)
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Lacquer boxes Gifts Marriage customs and rites
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The post-war period saw the establishment of several famous Chinese restaurants in Tua Po (Kreta Ayer area), including Nantang Restaurant at 8 Mosque Street and Da Dong Restaurant, which was just a few doors away on the same street. Judging from the five-digit telephone number on the box, it is possibly dated to the fifties and sixties. It was imported from Hong Kong, with the name of the import company or the lacquerware maker inscribed on its base.      
The box, made of bamboo and lacquered in an auspicious red, was traditionally used as a container for wedding pastries. The bride’s family would distribute boxes of these to relatives and friends ahead of the wedding, often together with the wedding invitation card.
